verses.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
भूय एव महाबाहो शृणु मे परमं वचः ।
यत्तेऽहं प्रीयमाणाय वक्ष्यामि हितकाम्यया ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
bhūya eva mahā-bāho śṛṇu me paramaṃ vacaḥ
yat te 'haṃ prīyamāṇāya vakṣyāmi hita-kāmyayā
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord speaks again, out of boundless love for His devotee: 'Hear Me once more, O mighty soul, for I desire only your highest good.' The Divine speaks not from duty but from love — every sacred teaching flows from God's longing to awaken the sleeping soul within us.

word_breakdown.meaning: out of a desire for your good / with the wish to benefit you / from pure goodwill

commentary.dadaji: Notice how Krishna opens this great chapter — not with philosophy, but with love. He says 'I will speak to you because you are dear to me, because I desire your welfare.' This is the language of a grandfather, of a true well-wisher. Krishna does not teach to display his wisdom — he teaches because he loves Arjuna. And bhūya eva — 'again, once more' — shows his inexhaustible patience. He has already given so much in chapters past, yet here he offers still more. The word hita-kāmyayā is precious — it means 'out of a desire for your good.' Your welfare, your liberation — that is why the divine speaks to you. Whenever you sit with the Gita, feel this: the Lord is speaking to you personally, out of love, desiring only your highest good. That feeling alone is half the teaching.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The chapter opens with two words that together form a complete statement of the guru-disciple relationship: prīyamāṇāya — 'to the one who is dear' — and hita-kāmyayā — 'desiring your welfare.' In Vedantic tradition, the teacher speaks the highest truth only to one who is both a qualified disciple and genuinely beloved. Śaṅkarācārya notes that prīyamāṇāya does not merely mean affection in a personal sense — it signals that Arjuna has become fit (adhikārī) through his earnestness and openness. The word paramaṃ vacaḥ — supreme word — indicates what follows transcends all ordinary instruction. The teaching of vibhūti and yoga in this chapter is meant to bring the disciple to the recognition that the entire universe is a manifestation of the one Self.
commentary.yogananda: When the divine teacher says 'hear again,' he is pointing to a law of spiritual reception: the highest truths must be heard repeatedly, in deepening states of consciousness, before they are truly absorbed. Paramahansa Yogananda often told his disciples: each time you read the Gita with focused attention, you receive it at a different level of your being. The words prīyamāṇāya — to the beloved — reveal the secret of spiritual transmission. The highest wisdom flows only through the channel of love. Where there is love between teacher and disciple, the words carry not merely meaning but vibration — a living current of awakening. Hita-kāmyayā shows us that divine grace is not indifferent; it is actively directed toward our liberation.
commentary.goyandka: Bhagavān Śrī Kṛṣṇa begins Chapter Ten by indicating that what follows is paramaṃ vacaḥ — the supreme teaching. The word bhūyas (again) shows continuity with the preceding chapter while signifying that an even higher exposition is about to be given. The qualification prīyamāṇāya is important: this teaching is given to one who is dear — signifying the disciple's purity of heart and eligibility. Hita-kāmyayā establishes the motive of the teacher as purely benevolent — not for any personal gain but solely for the disciple's spiritual upliftment. The Gita Press commentary emphasizes that the Lord's willingness to repeat and deepen the teaching shows his inexhaustible compassion for the sincere seeker.

verses.sanskrit:
न मे विदुः सुरगणाः प्रभवं न महर्षयः ।
अहमादिर्हि देवानां महर्षीणां च सर्वशः ॥
verses.transliteration:

aham ādir hi devānāṃ maharṣīṇāṃ ca sarvaśaḥ
verses.translation: Neither angels in celestial realms nor the greatest sages comprehend My origin — for I am the very Source from which both gods and sages arise. The Infinite cannot be measured by the finite mind; the Ocean is not known by studying its waves.

commentary.dadaji: Here Krishna reveals something that should stop us in our tracks: even the gods — Indra, Brahma, all the great celestial beings — do not know His origin. Even the great sages who have meditated for thousands of years do not know it. Why? Because He is their origin. How can a wave know the ocean that gave birth to it? This is not Krishna being mysterious or secretive — it is the simple, breathtaking truth of what He is. The very capacity these gods and sages have to think, to exist, to seek — all of that flows from Him. When you sit quietly and ask 'Where did I come from? What am I?' — you are asking the question that even the gods cannot answer about Him. Rest in that wonder, dear one. It is a doorway.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse makes a stunning epistemological declaration: the highest beings in the cosmic order — the devas and the maharṣis — cannot know the prabhava, the origin, of Brahman. Why not? Because Krishna states: 'I am the ādi — the first — of the gods and sages, in every way.' The cause cannot be known by the effect. Brahman is the ground from which all knowing and all beings arise; it cannot itself be grasped as an object of that knowing. This is the neti neti of the Upanishads expressed through the mouth of the divine teacher. The intellects of gods and sages — however refined — are still finite instruments. The infinite cannot be circumscribed by the finite. This is why Advaita does not say 'know Brahman' in the subject-object sense, but rather 'be Brahman.'
commentary.yogananda: The gods and sages cannot know Krishna's origin because they are themselves waves in the ocean of His consciousness. Yogananda often described this using the metaphor of light: just as you cannot see the source of light by using that same light to look for it, the mind — which is itself a ray of divine consciousness — cannot locate the source of its own illumination through ordinary inquiry. This verse is an invitation to meditation. In the stillness beyond thought, beyond even the activity of the highest refined intellect, something opens. That opening is not a 'knowing' in the ordinary sense — it is a dissolving into what was always already there. The gods seek; the realized soul is.
commentary.goyandka: Bhagavān declares here the inconceivability of His own origin — a foundational truth that distinguishes the Supreme from all other beings, however elevated. Sura-gaṇāḥ — the celestial hosts — and maharṣayaḥ — the greatest of sages — represent the highest possible levels of cosmic intelligence. Yet even they do not know His prabhavam, His ultimate origin and mode of manifestation. The reason given is decisive: aham ādiḥ — I am the very beginning of the gods and sages. No effect can comprehend its own cause in its totality. This verse prepares the ground for the subsequent teaching of vibhūtis — the divine manifestations — by establishing that Krishna as the absolute ground of all being cannot be grasped through any created intelligence.

asammūḍhaḥ sa martyeṣu sarva-pāpaiḥ pramucyate

commentary.dadaji: Three words carry this verse: ajam — unborn. Anādim — beginningless. Loka-maheśvaram — the great lord of all worlds. The one who truly knows this about Krishna becomes asammūḍhaḥ — undeluded. Not just intellectually convinced, but inwardly clear, settled, free. And then the beautiful promise: sarva-pāpaiḥ pramucyate — freed from all sins. Not some sins, not most sins — all. Sin, in the deepest sense, is the mistake of identifying with what is born and dying, of mistaking the temporary for the permanent. When you see that Krishna is unborn, beginningless, you begin to recognize that same unborn quality in yourself — the Atman that was never born, never dies. That recognition is liberation itself. Knowledge of God frees us, dear one.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse crystallizes the Vedantic understanding: liberation comes from right knowledge. Yo mām ajam anādiṃ vetti — the one who knows Me as unborn, beginningless. This is not merely belief or devotion in the popular sense — it is jñāna, discriminative knowledge of the ultimate nature of reality. Aja — unborn — corresponds directly to the Upanishadic characterization of Brahman: ajo nityaḥ śāśvato 'yaṃ purāṇaḥ. The result of this knowledge is asammūḍha — freedom from moha, from delusion. Moha is precisely the Gita's diagnosis of Arjuna's problem in the first chapter. Its cure is this clear seeing. And the outcome — sarva-pāpaiḥ pramucyate — freedom from all pāpa — is not a moral reward but an ontological shift: when the root delusion dissolves, its effects — all forms of bondage — dissolve with it.
commentary.yogananda: To know Krishna as unborn and beginningless is to know the eternal Self that underlies all appearances. Yogananda taught that the great masters do not merely believe in God's infinity — they perceive it directly, in states of samādhi, where the boundaries of individual consciousness dissolve into boundless awareness. The one who achieves this knowledge — even partially, even as a growing intuition — becomes asammūḍhaḥ, inwardly freed from the confusions that torment ordinary consciousness. All sin, in Yogananda's teaching, ultimately traces back to the original error of cosmic delusion — māyā — which convinces us we are separate from the infinite. When that delusion lifts, the cause of all sin is removed at the root.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is the direct sequel to verse 2: having established that even gods and sages cannot know His origin, Krishna now declares what happens when a human being does know. Three qualities are named: aja (unborn), anādi (beginningless), and loka-maheśvara (the supreme lord of all worlds). These three together define the absolute nature of the Supreme. The result of this knowledge is twofold: the knower becomes asammūḍhaḥ — free of all delusion — and is pramucyate — fully liberated from all pāpa. Goyandka notes that pāpa here is to be understood comprehensively: not merely sinful actions but the entire web of karma, both good and bad, that binds the jīva to the cycle of birth and death. Knowledge of the absolute nature of God is itself the liberating force.

commentary.dadaji: Here Krishna begins a beautiful, sweeping list — and what a list it is. He does not just name virtues like buddhi and kṣamā, which we might expect. He names sukha and duḥkha, bhava and abhāva — pleasure, pain, birth, death. He names bhaya — fear — and abhaya — fearlessness. All of these, he will say in the next verse, arise from Him alone. Your moments of joy? From Him. Your hours of grief? From Him. Your fear and your courage? Both from Him. This is not a cold philosophical statement. It is an invitation to see the divine face behind every experience of your life — not just the pleasant ones. The next time you are afraid, dear one, remember: even this fear has its source in the same God whose peace you seek.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verses 4 and 5 together form a catalogue of the bhāvas — the psychological and existential conditions of all beings. They are to be read as a single statement: all of these arise from Krishna alone (verse 5 closes: matta eva pṛthag-vidhāḥ). What is remarkable is the range: buddhi (intelligence), jñāna (knowledge), asaṃmoha (freedom from delusion) — these are the highest spiritual qualities. But then: sukha-duḥkha (pleasure and pain), bhava-abhāva (existence and non-existence), bhaya-abhaya (fear and fearlessness). The list encompasses the entire spectrum of inner life. In Advaita, this is a statement of non-dual causation: Brahman is the material and efficient cause of all that exists, including all states of the mind. There is nothing — not even delusion — that is outside of Brahman.
commentary.yogananda: In listing buddhi and jñāna alongside sukha, duḥkha, bhaya, and abhaya, Krishna is revealing the unity behind all apparent opposites. Yogananda saw in this teaching a profound metaphysical law: every quality and every experience in this universe is a vibration of the one divine consciousness, polarized into pairs of opposites — pleasure/pain, fear/fearlessness, birth/death. These opposites are not separate realities; they are two poles of a single current emanating from God. The practice of yoga is to trace every experience — joyful or painful — back to its source. The meditator learns, in deep stillness, that the one who experiences pleasure and the one who experiences pain are both movements of the same infinite awareness.
commentary.goyandka: In verse 4, Bhagavān begins the enumeration of the bhāvās — the conditions and qualities — that arise from Him alone. The first group — buddhi, jñāna, asaṃmoha, kṣamā, satya, dama, śama — represents the sattvic qualities that qualify a soul for liberation. But then the list extends to the apparently opposite pair: sukha and duḥkha (pleasure and pain), bhava and abhāva (birth and non-being), bhaya and abhaya (fear and fearlessness). These are not moral qualities but existential conditions — yet Krishna claims them all as His vibhūtis. Goyandka emphasizes that this is a teaching about divine sovereignty: nothing in the created order exists outside the will and power of the Lord. Even conditions that appear opposed to liberation are under His governance.

verses.sanskrit:
अहिंसा समता तुष्टिस्तपो दानं यशोऽयशः ।
भवन्ति भावा भूतानां मत्त एव पृथग्विधाः ॥

commentary.dadaji: Krishna closes this magnificent pair of verses with matta eva — from Me alone. This is the punch of the teaching: every single bhāva — every quality, every condition, every state of a being — arises from Him and from no other. Ahiṃsā, the highest virtue of the saints, arises from Him. Yaśa — fame — and ayaśa — infamy — both arise from Him. Even the darkness that clings to a person's name arises from the same divine source as the light of their virtue. My grandfather used to say: when you can see God's hand in everything — in your successes and your shaming failures, in your fame and your obscurity — then you are free. The ego no longer has anything to cling to or run from. Matta eva. All from Him alone.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 5 completes the declaration begun in verse 4. The closing line is the key: bhavanti bhāvā bhūtānāṃ matta eva pṛthag-vidhāḥ — all the various modes of all beings arise from Me alone. Pṛthag-vidhāḥ — different in kind — acknowledges the genuine diversity of experience: ahiṃsā is not the same as yaśa, and samatā is not the same as ayaśa. Yet all these differences arise from the single, undivided source. This is the Advaita teaching of vivartavāda applied to psychology and ethics: the many apparent forms are not independent realities but manifestations of the one. The practical implication: whatever you encounter in yourself or others — virtue or vice, fame or shame — do not be disturbed. See through the form to the one source.
commentary.yogananda: Ahiṃsā stands first in this final list — and Yogananda saw in this a profound teaching. Non-violence is not merely a rule against harm; it is a state of consciousness that arises when one perceives the Self in all beings. You do not harm what you recognize as your own deeper nature. Similarly, samatā — equanimity — is not emotional blankness but the natural state of a mind that has tasted its identity with the immovable ground of consciousness. The inclusion of yaśa and ayaśa — fame and infamy — is particularly striking. Krishna is saying: even the way the world perceives you, even your reputation, is in my hands alone. The liberated soul neither chases fame nor flees infamy. It rests in the knowing: matta eva — from Me alone.
commentary.goyandka: This verse completes the two-verse enumeration of divine qualities and conditions. The list in verse 5 begins with the highest ethical virtue — ahiṃsā — and concludes with the pair yaśa and ayaśa (fame and infamy). The closing declaration — matta eva pṛthag-vidhāḥ — means that all these diverse modes of existence arise exclusively from the Lord. Goyandka draws attention to the word eva (alone, certainly), which admits no exception: there is no state of any being, however exalted or degraded, that falls outside the sovereignty of God. This is not fatalism but theism of the highest order: the Lord is not a distant creator but the living, present source from which every quality of every being ceaselessly arises.

commentary.dadaji: The seven sages and the four Manus — they were born directly from the mind of God. Mānasāḥ jātāḥ — mind-born. And from them, all the world's beings were generated. This is the great cosmic family tree — and it begins not in a laboratory, not in chance, but in the divine mind's creative intention. You and I, dear one, trace our ancestry to those luminous sages and progenitors who arose directly from Krishna's own thought. We are, in a very real sense, grandchildren of the divine. The verse deepens what was said in verses 2 and 3: because Krishna is the origin of the gods and sages, and because all humanity flows from those sages, the lineage of every living being flows back to the one unborn, beginningless Lord. We are all children of God — literally.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse grounds the metaphysical claims of the preceding verses in the cosmological tradition. The saptarṣis and four Manus are the first level of manifestation between pure consciousness and embodied humanity. Crucially, they are described as mad-bhāvā — imbued with My nature — and mānasā jātā — born of My mind. In Advaita, this is the teaching of sṛṣṭi-vāda at the cosmic level: the divine mind (the Logos, as it were) projects the primordial sages and ancestors, who then generate the multiplicity of creation. What is remarkable is that these progenitors are not separate from God — they are mad-bhāvāḥ, they partake of His nature. Creation is not a falling away from God but an expression of God's own being.
commentary.yogananda: The seven rishis and four Manus represent the first mind-born children of cosmic consciousness — the original templates from which the diversity of human and cosmic life was patterned. Yogananda taught that the great sages were not merely historical figures but are living cosmic forces, present in every age, guiding evolution from the causal plane. Mānasā jātāḥ — born of the mind — points to the primacy of consciousness in all creation. Matter does not give rise to mind; mind gives rise to matter. The entire universe is a mental projection of divine consciousness — and the seven sages, as its first mind-born emanations, carry within them the template of that consciousness. In each soul, this primordial sage-nature lies dormant, waiting to be awakened.
commentary.goyandka: This verse establishes the secondary cosmic genealogy: after the gods and great seers of verse 2, Krishna now names the seven maharṣis (traditionally Marīci, Atri, Aṅgiras, Pulastya, Pulaha, Kratu, Vasiṣṭha) and the four primordial Manus as His mind-born progeny. They are mad-bhāvāḥ — possessing His nature — and from them all the world's beings are born. Goyandka notes the significance of the phrase mānasā jātāḥ: these sages did not originate through the physical process of procreation but arose directly from the Lord's sankalpa — His divine will and mental intention. This is a cosmological statement of total divine sovereignty: the entire chain of creation, from its highest to its most humble link, originates in the Lord.

commentary.dadaji: Krishna ends with nātra saṃśayaḥ — there is no doubt about this. When has Krishna ever been so direct? The promise is total: whoever truly understands His vibhūti and yoga is united by avikampena yoga — yoga that does not shake. Not temporary union, not occasional glimpses of peace — but an unwavering, steady, unbreakable yoga. The word tattvataḥ is important: not superficial understanding, not intellectual information, but deep, real knowing. What is the knowing? That Krishna's glory pervades all creation — that the beauty you see in the world, the intelligence in beings, the love in relationships — all of this is His vibhūti. When that knowing stabilizes in you, the yoga becomes avikampena — unshaking. Nothing can destabilize one who sees God everywhere.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The verse introduces the key term of this chapter: vibhūti. The word literally means 'that which pervades abundantly' — the specific, particularized expressions through which the infinite makes itself visible in finite forms. Yogam here refers not merely to the practice of yoga but to the yoga-śakti — the divine power by which the Lord holds creation together. To know both vibhūti (the manifestation) and yoga (the power behind it) tattvataḥ — in truth — is to know the relationship between the many and the One, between form and the formless. The result is avikampena yoga — unwavering union. This is not a future reward; it is the immediate fruit of genuine insight. When the non-dual nature of reality is truly seen, the mind naturally settles into a unity that cannot be disturbed by the play of opposites.
commentary.yogananda: Tattvataḥ — truly, in reality — is Yogananda's key word here. Superficial knowledge of spiritual truths produces superficial results. But when the meditator, in deep stillness, directly perceives the divine energy (vibhūti) pervading all forms, and recognizes the yoga — the seamless connection — between the individual soul and its source, something permanent shifts. The wavering of the mind — its habitual movement between fear and hope, attraction and repulsion — gradually settles into what Krishna calls avikampena yoga: unwavering union. This is what Yogananda described as the goal of Kriya Yoga — not just temporary states of peace, but a stable, unshakable realization of one's unity with the divine. Nātra saṃśayaḥ — no doubt about it.
commentary.goyandka: This verse promises the supreme fruit of the teaching that follows in the rest of Chapter Ten: avikampena yoga — absolutely steady, unwavering union with the divine. The condition is tattvataḥ vetti — one who truly knows. Superficial acquaintance with the list of vibhūtis is not sufficient; what is required is tattva-jñāna, the knowledge of the real nature of the Lord's manifestation and His divine power (yoga). The phrase nātra saṃśayaḥ — there is no doubt here — is a direct guarantee from the Lord Himself. Goyandka notes that this guarantee is unconditional: the knowledge of God's all-pervasiveness leads without fail to steady union, because such knowledge leaves no room for the distractions and attachments that cause the yoga to waver.

commentary.dadaji: This verse is one of the great summits of the Gita. Ahaṃ sarvasya prabhavaḥ — I am the origin of all. Mattaḥ sarvaṃ pravartate — from Me all things proceed. And then: knowing this, the wise worship Me with bhāva-samanvitāḥ — with deep feeling, with their whole heart. Not out of obligation, not out of fear, but endowed with emotion. Real bhakti is never dry, never merely intellectual. It is warm, alive, full. When the budha — the truly awakened person — understands that the whole of existence flows from Krishna, what rises in them is not cold acceptance but radiant love and devotion. My grandfather used to say: if you truly knew where everything comes from, your heart would weep and sing at the same time. Bhāva — that living, breathing devotional feeling — is the sign that true understanding has arrived.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 8 is the philosophical axis of Chapter Ten, indeed of the entire devotional teaching of the Gita. Ahaṃ sarvasya prabhavaḥ — I am the origin of everything — is the full statement of the Advaita principle that Brahman is both the material and efficient cause of creation. Mattaḥ sarvaṃ pravartate — everything proceeds from Me. This is not the teaching of a distant creator God who fashions the world from outside; this is the teaching of an indwelling, all-pervading consciousness from which creation is not separate. The response of the wise (budhāḥ) to this understanding is striking: they worship — bhajante — not despite their wisdom but because of it. True jñāna, in this verse, flowers into bhakti. Knowledge of the all-pervading source naturally produces devotion, because the one who knows that source knows it as the most intimate reality of their own being.
commentary.yogananda: This verse is the meeting point of jñāna and bhakti in the Gita's teaching. The wise know — iti matvā — that all things proceed from the one divine source. But the knowing is not cold or detached: it is accompanied by bhāva — deep inner feeling. Yogananda taught that in the highest states of samādhi, the distinction between knowing God and loving God dissolves. The experience of divine omnipresence — 'all this flows from Me' — is simultaneously an experience of being held, loved, and sustained by that omnipresence. The word bhajante is pregnant: it comes from the root √bhaj, to share, to participate in. The wise do not merely observe God from a distance; they participate in the divine life, they share in it, they become it.
commentary.goyandka: Ahaṃ sarvasya prabhavaḥ — Krishna declares Himself to be the prabhava, the ultimate source and origin, of the entire universe. This is a statement of absolute divine causality: nothing exists, nothing moves, nothing proceeds except from the Lord. The wise (budhāḥ) respond to this knowledge not with passive acceptance but with active worship — bhajante — endowed with bhāva (feeling, love, devotion). Goyandka emphasizes the word matvā — 'having understood' — as the causative link: it is specifically because they have truly understood His omnipresence that the wise worship with such fullness of feeling. Understanding without devotion is incomplete; devotion born of understanding is the highest expression of human spiritual life.

commentary.dadaji: Can you picture the scene this verse describes? A gathering of devotees — talking about Krishna, waking each other up to His presence, finding complete satisfaction and joy in that sharing. Mac-cittāḥ — minds fixed on Me. Mad-gata-prāṇāḥ — even their prāṇa, their very life-breath, has gone to Me. And what do they do together? They enlighten one another — bodhayantaḥ parasparam — and they speak of Me — kathayantaś ca māṃ nityam. Not occasionally, not when there is nothing better to do — nityam, always. And the fruit? Tuṣyanti ca ramanti ca — they are satisfied and they delight. Both words — tuṣṭi and rati — describe a complete inner fullness that wants nothing more. This is what satsang means. This is why the company of the divine and of those who love the divine is the greatest treasure of spiritual life.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse describes the community of the awakened — the satsaṅga — as a living organism of mutual enlightenment. Mac-cittāḥ — minds established in the Lord. Mad-gata-prāṇāḥ — the very prāṇa, the vital force, gone to Him. These are not people who think of God occasionally; God has become the center of gravity of their entire existence. Bodhayantaḥ parasparam — they awaken one another. In the Vedantic tradition, this mutual awakening is more than social encouragement; it is the transmission of understanding. When someone who has truly seen the non-dual truth speaks, their words carry a resonance that can ignite recognition in the listener. This is why the tradition places such emphasis on sat-saṅga — the company of those who have the sat, the real. Tuṣyanti and ramanti — contentment and delight — are the natural fruits.
commentary.yogananda: Mac-cittāḥ — consciousness fixed in Me. Mad-gata-prāṇāḥ — life-force absorbed in Me. These two compound adjectives describe the two-fold absorption that Yogananda identified as the state of the true bhakta: the mind (citta) is gathered into the awareness of God, and the prāṇa — the very energy of life — flows toward God rather than outward toward sensory objects. In Kriya Yoga, this is not metaphor but physiology: the practice literally reverses the outward flow of prāṇa and draws it inward and upward. The community described here — enlightening each other, speaking of the Lord — is the ideal of the spiritual community or āśram, where every conversation, every meal, every activity, is an occasion for mutual awakening. Such a community generates a field of collective consciousness that sustains and accelerates each member's realization.
commentary.goyandka: This verse portrays the daily life of the true bhakta who has taken the understanding of verse 8 to heart. Three features characterize their inner state: mac-cittāḥ (mind fixed on the Lord), mad-gata-prāṇāḥ (life-energy absorbed in the Lord), and nityam kathayantaḥ (ever speaking of the Lord). These are not intermittent practices but the permanent orientation of their existence. Goyandka notes that bodhayantaḥ parasparam — mutually enlightening one another — describes the ideal of sādhu-satsaṅga: the association of seekers who together sustain and deepen one another's understanding. The fruits are tuṣyanti (they are satisfied — inner contentment) and ramanti (they delight — inner joy). These two together indicate a completeness of spiritual experience: neither restless nor inert, but joyfully fulfilled.

commentary.dadaji: This, dear one, is one of the most precious verses in all of scripture. Dadāmi — I give. Not 'they earn,' not 'they achieve,' not 'they develop through effort.' I give. The Lord Himself gives the buddhi-yoga — the very intelligence and inner clarity by which the soul finds its way home. And when? When two conditions are met: satata-yuktānām — ever steadfastly united with Him — and prīti-pūrvakam — with love, out of love, rooted in love. Not fear-based worship, not transaction-based prayer — love. Pure love. Then God reaches into the devotee's own intelligence and illuminates it from within. This is divine grace. Buddhi-yoga here is not something we practice; it is something we receive — from the hands of the Lord, directly, because He loves those who love Him. Can you feel the tenderness? I give. He gives.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 10 is among the most theologically significant in the Gita, touching the question of divine grace (anugraha) in relation to human effort. Satata-yuktānām — of those ever steadfastly united — describes the human side of the equation: the practice of continuous self-alignment with the divine. Prīti-pūrvakam — with love — is the quality of that practice: not mechanical, not transactional, but rooted in genuine bhāva. And then: dadāmi — I give. The Lord is the direct giver of buddhi-yoga — the discriminative wisdom that enables the final breakthrough to liberation. In Advaita, this is the role of Īśvara's grace: the jīva's effort purifies the mind and makes it fit; the Lord's grace, as the inner Witness, illuminates the buddhi with the self-luminous knowledge of Brahman. Yena mām upayānti — by which they come to Me: the goal is non-different from the giver.
commentary.yogananda: Buddhi-yoga — the yoga of intelligence — is, in Yogananda's understanding, the awakening of the divine intuitive faculty that transcends both sensory perception and ordinary rational thought. It is the awakening of the spiritual eye — the jñāna-cakṣuḥ — that perceives the divine reality directly. And Krishna says: dadāmi — I give it. This is the secret of bhakti: the devotee does not reach God by the strength of their own intellect. Rather, when the heart is opened fully in love (prīti-pūrvakam), the divine itself illumines the disciple's intelligence from within. In deep meditation, this gift is received not as an intellectual insight but as a shift in the quality of awareness — a sudden, unmistakable clarity in which the path to God becomes visible and the soul moves toward its source with certainty. Nātra saṃśayaḥ — no doubt about it.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is the crown of the opening section of Chapter Ten. Two qualifications are named for the recipients of divine grace: satata-yuktāḥ (ever steadfastly united with the Lord) and bhajantaḥ prīti-pūrvakam (worshipping with love and joy). To such devotees, the Lord directly gives — dadāmi — buddhi-yogam, the yoga of discriminative intelligence. Goyandka emphasizes that this buddhi-yoga is not merely the capacity for philosophical analysis but the specific divine intelligence that enables the soul to perceive God clearly and move toward Him without obstruction. The verse establishes a perfect circuit: the devotee loves and serves, God illumines the intelligence, the illumined intelligence brings the devotee to God. The word yena — 'by which' — shows the instrumental role of buddhi-yoga: it is the vehicle of final attainment. The chapter's opening promise of welfare (hita-kāmyayā, v.1) is here fulfilled.

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the most comforting verses in the entire Gita. The Lord does not wait outside for us to come to Him — He is seated in our very heart, in the innermost chamber of our being, and He personally holds the lamp of wisdom to dispel our darkness. What kind of teacher travels inside the student's heart to give the lesson? Only God. This is why the Guru is revered as God — because the inner Guru and the outer Guru are ultimately one. When you sit quietly in meditation and a moment of clarity comes — that is Krishna, lamp in hand, burning away the fog.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Kena Upanishad opens with the question: 'By whose will does the mind go forth?' — pointing to the inner controller who is both the witness and the illuminator of all mental activity. Krishna here identifies Himself as that inner Ātman who, out of compassion (anukampā), destroys the darkness of avidyā. This is not an external operation but an interior transformation — the Self revealing itself to itself. The 'lamp of wisdom' (jñānadīpa) recalls the Mundaka Upanishad's image: 'Two birds sit on one branch — one eats the fruits, the other watches.' The watching bird is the Ātman; when its presence becomes known, the eating bird is liberated.
commentary.yogananda: The Lord as the inner guru — seated in the cave of the heart — is one of the great revelations of this chapter. Advanced meditators discover this directly: in the silence of deep meditation, a luminous intelligence guides the mind beyond its own boundaries. This is not imagination but actual contact with the immanent Presence. The lamp of wisdom (jñānadīpa) corresponds to the spiritual eye — the single eye of which Christ spoke, located at the ajna chakra. When this inner light is kindled through devotion and meditation, the darkness of the ego-self dissolves in an instant of brilliant recognition. All is God.
commentary.goyandka: This verse reveals the unique grace (anugraha) of the Lord toward His devotees — while the path of karma yoga or jñāna yoga requires the individual's sustained effort, the path of complete surrender (prapatti) calls forth the Lord's direct intervention. He is not merely the object of meditation but the active subject within — ātmabhāvasthaḥ, dwelling as the very Self. The lamp of jñāna is traditionally the guru's grace, but here Krishna reveals that the highest guru-śakti is nothing other than the inner Ātman Itself. The Brahma-sūtras state 'śāstrā-yonitvāt' — the scriptures are the source of knowledge; but Krishna goes deeper: He is the living light within the scriptural letter.

commentary.dadaji: This is Arjuna's great hymn of recognition — spoken not from fear or flattery, but from the depths of a heart that has been moved by love and insight. He uses every great name for the Absolute — Brahman, the supreme abode, the purifier, the eternal Purusha, the unborn, the all-pervading. This is how the devotee naturally speaks when the heart opens: all inadequate words tumble out, each one trying and failing to contain the beloved. The spiritual student who reads this verse should feel it as their own declaration — not recited as theology, but lived as recognition. 'You are all this, my Lord.'
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's proclamation here beautifully synthesises the key Vedantic descriptions of Brahman: paramam brahma (echoing the Mundaka: 'brahmaivedam amṛtam purastāt'), paraṃ dhāma (the supreme substratum), and pavitraṃ paramam (supreme purity, which is the nature of śuddha-caitanya). The declaration 'ādidevam ajam' directly resonates with the Kaṭha Upanishad's 'nāyam ātmā pravacanena labhyo' — the Self is not born and cannot be obtained through mere discursive knowledge. When a disciple can genuinely say this — not as memorised theology but as living experience — the teaching has truly been received.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna has been transformed by the teaching of the preceding ten chapters. What began as grief and confusion (Chapter 1) has deepened into luminous recognition: 'You are the Supreme Brahman.' This is the goal of all spiritual seeking — to look upon the face of one's teacher, one's guru, and recognise the Divine. The 'supreme abode' (paraṃ dhāma) is not a place in the heavens but the state of pure consciousness — the place the soul arrives at when it finally rests in the Self. Unborn, all-pervading — these are the marks of the Absolute; and yet here it stands in human form, speaking kindly to a bewildered devotee.
commentary.goyandka: Verses 12-15 constitute Arjuna's stotra (hymn of praise) in recognition of the Lord's supreme nature — this is the appropriate response of the śiṣya who has received the teaching with reverence. 'Paraṃ brahma paraṃ dhāma' identifies Krishna with the nirguna Brahman of the Upanishads as well as the saguna Brahman of theistic devotion. 'Ādidevam ajam' places Krishna at the very origin of the cosmic hierarchy — He is not one deity among many but the source from which all manifestations arise. This verse serves as the disciple's samarpana — a complete surrender of one's understanding to the Teacher who has been recognised as none other than the Supreme.

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna is not relying only on his own experience — he validates what Krishna has told him by saying: the sages confirm this. Narada, Asita, Devala, Vyasa — these are the great rivers of human wisdom, all flowing to the same ocean. And then Arjuna adds, most beautifully: 'and You Yourself tell me so.' There is something childlike and complete about this faith — when the greatest teachers of history all point to the same truth, and then the truth itself speaks directly to your heart, what else is needed? This is how faith matures into knowledge: gradually corroborated from all directions until there is no remaining doubt.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's appeal to the authority of the sages reflects the Vedantic epistemological framework of the 'triple testimony' (trī prasthāna): śruti (scripture), smṛti (tradition), and anubhava (direct experience). Narada's authority comes from direct revelation; Asita and Devala represent the dharmaśāstra tradition; Vyasa represents the synthesis of all Vedic wisdom in the Mahabharata and Puranas. And then Arjuna adds the fourth and supreme authority: svayam bravīṣi — 'You Yourself tell me so.' This is the beauty of bhakti: the devotee eventually needs no external authority at all, for the Divine speaks directly within.
commentary.yogananda: The tradition of wisdom is like a great unbroken chain — each authentic sage passes the light of truth to the next generation. Narada, the celestial messenger of bhakti, carries this light across all three worlds without interruption. When Arjuna says 'You Yourself tell me so,' he is describing the highest form of spiritual knowing: direct revelation, where the teacher and the teaching and the taught become one. This is what the great Christian mystics called 'locutio Dei' — the speech of God within — and what the Vedic tradition calls 'aparokṣānubhūti' — direct, non-mediated experience of the Real.
commentary.goyandka: The tradition (sampradāya) is essential in Vedic dharma — no individual can claim spiritual authority in isolation. Here Arjuna establishes that his recognition of Krishna's divine nature is not merely personal but corroborated by the entire paraṃparā (lineage) of sages from Narada to Vyasa. Devarṣi Nārada transmits knowledge through bhakti and revelation; Asita and Devala represent the ancient dharmaśāstra tradition; Vyāsadeva, who is the guru of gurus and an avatāra in his own right, provides the ultimate scriptural sanction. The final clause — 'svayaṃ caiva bravīṣi me' — acknowledges that no external authority is more valid than the direct teaching of Bhagavān Himself.

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's faith here is complete and wholehearted — 'I believe all this as true.' This is śraddhā — not blind credulity, but a deep, quiet confidence born of love and resonance. Notice that even the gods cannot fully comprehend Krishna's nature — this should inspire appropriate humility in us. The highest theological formulations, the most sophisticated philosophical systems, can only point from a distance at what the devotee in love experiences in a moment. Arjuna calls Krishna 'Keshava' — whose very name can mean 'the one who destroys Keshi (the demon),' and at another level means 'the beautiful-haired one.' Even in address, every name is praise.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Ṛtam — cosmic truth — is the Vedic term for the fundamental order underlying all existence, the ground of all dharma. Arjuna's acceptance of ṛtam is his alignment with this cosmic truth-principle. The statement that neither gods nor demons know Krishna's vyakti (manifestation/nature) reflects the Upanishadic teaching that Brahman is beyond the grasp of even the celestial intelligences: 'yato vāco nivartante aprāpya manasā saha' — where speech and mind return without reaching. The gods partake of Brahman's light but cannot encompass it; this is precisely why even Indra must take instruction from Brihaspati, and why all wisdom ultimately traces back to the Supreme.
commentary.yogananda: The gods and demons in this verse represent, at an inner level, all the various powers and tendencies of the mind and the spiritual realm — none of them can truly know the infinite consciousness that is Krishna. Even the highest angels exist within the framework of relative consciousness; the Absolute transcends all relative knowledge. Arjuna's faith — 'I believe all this as true' — is the beginning of direct knowledge (aparokṣa jñāna). When we cease arguing with God and simply open in trust, the barriers dissolve and the Light enters. This is the transformative power of śraddhā: it opens the door that intellectual analysis cannot.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's declaration 'sarvam etad ṛtam manye' is the proper attitude of the śiṣya: accepting the guru's word with full śraddhā, not as servile credulity but as the natural response of a purified intellect that recognizes the teaching as consonant with both scripture and inner experience. The statement that neither devas nor dānavas know the Lord's true vyakti establishes the transcendence of the Supreme over all cosmic hierarchies — this is the philosophical basis for the Vedantic doctrine that Brahman is svayam-prakāśa (self-luminous) and cannot be known as an object. The devotee who surrenders completely, paradoxically, comes closest to this unknowable Lord — through love what intellect cannot reach.

commentary.dadaji: This verse reaches the limit of what words can do. After all the names and praises, Arjuna arrives at this: 'Only You know Yourself through Yourself.' The mind cannot reach God — only God can reach God. And then, like a garland being placed at the feet of the Lord, the four titles tumble out: Source of beings, Lord of beings, God of gods, Lord of the universe. These are not intellectual propositions — they are acts of love. The devotee who speaks these words in prayer is not describing God; they are surrendering into God. The act of praise itself becomes a form of union.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This is perhaps the most radical epistemological statement in the Gita: Brahman knows Brahman — the Absolute is known only by the Absolute itself. This directly parallels the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad's 'vijñātaram are kena vijānīyāt' — 'By what should the knower be known?' The subject-object structure of ordinary knowledge breaks down completely at this point. The four vocatives — bhūtabhāvana, bhūteśa, devadeva, jagatpate — are progressively more encompassing: Creator, Lord, God of gods, Lord of all — each term pointing to a wider circle of divine sovereignty until the circle encompasses all existence.
commentary.yogananda: 'You alone know Yourself by Yourself' — this is the Vedantic axiom that Consciousness (Cit) alone can know pure Consciousness. No instrument, no faculty, no concept can grasp the Infinite — only the Infinite can know itself. In the deepest states of samadhi, the individual consciousness does not so much 'know' Brahman as it merges with Brahman, and in that merging there is a knowing that is not separate from being. The four divine names with which Arjuna concludes are a cascade of recognition — Source, Lord, God, Master — each one a wave of devotional awareness breaking on the shore of the Infinite.
commentary.goyandka: The principle svayam evātmanātmānaṃ vettha — the Lord knows Himself through Himself — is the Vedantic doctrine of Brahman as self-luminous (svaprakāśa) and self-knowing (svayaṃvedya). This is why no jīva can know Brahman as an external object — Brahman can only be known from within, as the knowing itself. The four epithets in the second line are a progressive hymn of attribution: bhūtabhāvana points to the sṛṣṭi (creation) function; bhūteśa to the sthiti (sustenance); devadeva to the sovereignty above all cosmic hierarchies; and jagatpate to the ultimate lordship over all of manifest existence. Arjuna's hymn thus encompasses the full pañcakṛtya (five divine functions) in compressed form.

commentary.dadaji: Now Arjuna asks for what every devotee secretly longs for: 'Tell me how You are everywhere.' Not just that You are everywhere — but how, specifically, I can see You. This question is the beginning of a new kind of seeing — learning to recognise the Divine in the world as it actually is, not just as an abstract principle. This is the practical bhakti question: 'In what forms should I meditate on You? What should I look for?' The Lord's answer — all the vibhutis of verses 20-42 — is a curriculum for sacred vision, a training manual for eyes that want to see God in creation.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's request — 'tell me fully, aśeṣeṇa' — contains a deep irony that Krishna gently corrects in verse 40: there is no 'fully' when it comes to Brahman's vibhutis; the most one can offer is a representative selection, an uddeśataḥ (indication). The question about how Krishna 'pervades and abides in' these worlds invites the distinction between the immanent and transcendent aspects of Brahman — He is both vyāpya (pervading, immanent) and sthita (abiding, transcendent). This is the Upanishadic 'aṇor aṇīyān mahato mahīyān' — smaller than the smallest, larger than the largest.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna is asking the cosmic meditator's question: 'Teach me to find You in everything.' This is the transition from introversion (finding God within, in meditation) to extroversion (finding God without, in the world). The fully realised yogi moves freely between these — in the inner stillness, the Absolute; in the outer movement, the same Absolute wearing the costume of creation. The teaching of the vibhutis is essentially a manual for cosmic meditation — for the contemplative who wishes to see God's face in every flower, every ocean wave, every act of human excellence.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's request that Krishna describe His divine manifestations (vibhūtayaḥ) in their totality represents the gurumukha's perfect posture: having received the philosophical teaching, he now asks for the devotional curriculum — how to apply this understanding in lived experience. The phrase 'vyāpya tiṣṭhasi' (pervading and abiding) encapsulates the non-dual presence: not that Krishna merely creates the worlds and stands apart, but that He pervades them from within while remaining beyond them — both saguṇa and nirguṇa, both immanent and transcendent. The following verses (20-42) constitute His gracious response to this sincere request.

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's question comes from a very practical place — 'How do I find You in daily meditation? In what forms should I think of You?' This is the question of the sincere sādhaka, not the philosopher. The answer that follows — the entire Vibhuti Yoga — is Krishna's gift to every meditator who has ever struggled with making the formless concrete, with anchoring the abstract in the tangible. Start with what you love most in creation — the sunrise, the river, the mountain — and know that you are touching Krishna. Gradually, everything becomes a face of the Beloved.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna addresses Krishna as 'Yogin' — recognising Him not merely as a deity but as the supreme practitioner of yoga, the one who has perfectly united individual consciousness with cosmic consciousness. The question 'in what aspects are You to be contemplated?' invites the teaching of saguṇa upāsanā — the meditative approach through definite forms and qualities, which is the starting point for most sādhakas before the mind can rest in formless awareness. Patanjali's Yoga Sutras begin with 'Ishvara-praṇidhāna' — surrender to the Lord — and this verse is essentially Arjuna asking how to practise that surrendered, continuous contemplation.
commentary.yogananda: The great meditators of all traditions have faced this same question: how to bring the infinite into the finite capacity of the human mind? The vibhutis that follow are Krishna's practical answer — meditate on the highest in every category, and you will be meditating on Me. In the scientific laboratory, meditate on Truth; in the concert hall, meditate on Beauty; in the forest, meditate on the ancient sacred trees. Everywhere, in every excellence, find the divine thread. This is the yoga of seeing, the practice of sacred perception that transforms ordinary life into continuous meditation.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's two-part question — 'how to know (vidyām)' and 'in what aspects to contemplate (keṣu bhāveṣu cintya)' — represents the dual inquiry of the sincere devotee: both the philosophical question (what is the nature of the Divine?) and the practical question (how do I access it?). The first is answered by the vibhūti-knowledge itself; the second is answered by the practice of seeing each vibhūti as a doorway. Traditional commentators note that this verse authorises the devotee to meditate on God's highest manifestations as a legitimate and indeed superior form of saguṇa upāsanā — the yoga of sacred seeing that prepares the mind for the nirguna realisation.

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna cannot get enough — he calls Krishna's words 'amṛtam,' nectar, and says he is not satisfied however much he hears. This is the mark of true spiritual experience: it creates an appetite rather than satiation. The more genuine contact you have with the Divine, the more you want. This is the opposite of worldly pleasure, which always disappoints and depletes. Krishna's words are called amṛta because they bring immortality — they touch something in the soul that death cannot reach. Every time you sit with the Gita and feel that inexhaustible pull, Arjuna's words are being fulfilled in you.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The image of the Lord's words as amṛta (nectar) is deeply Upanishadic — the Taittiriya Upanishad repeatedly uses the word 'ananda' (bliss) to describe the nature of Brahman, and this bliss, once tasted, creates an inexhaustible thirst for more. 'Bhūyaḥ kathaya' — 'tell me again' — reflects the nature of genuine spiritual inquiry: it is never complete, never exhausted. The Chhandogya Upanishad narrates how the young Svetaketu returns again and again to his father Uddalaka for deeper teaching; each answer opens to a wider question. This insatiability is not spiritual immaturity but spiritual health.
commentary.yogananda: When divine words touch the soul directly, they are experienced as amṛta — a sweet, sustaining nourishment that is literally undying (a-mṛta: without death). Sri Ramakrishna described the effect of hearing the name of God as like hearing a bell struck in an empty room — the reverberations continue long after the sound has ceased. Arjuna's hunger for more teaching shows that the earlier chapters have done their work: his heart has been opened, his consciousness has been raised, and now the divine teaching flows into him like rain into a field prepared for planting.
commentary.goyandka: The identification of Shri Krishna's words with amṛta (divine nectar) is echoed throughout the Bhāgavata Purāṇa — 'śṛṇvatāṃ sva-kathāḥ kṛṣṇaḥ' — the self-narratives of Krishna enter the heart of those who listen with faith and cleanse it like the Ganga. 'Tṛptir hi śṛṇvato nāsti me amṛtam' — this holy dissatisfaction is the correct state of the mumukṣu (one seeking liberation): worldly pleasures saturate and dull, while spiritual wisdom enlivens and invites ever-deeper inquiry. Arjuna calling the Lord 'Janārdana' — the one who aids humanity (jana=people, ardana=to help/stir) — places this personal exchange in its cosmic context: Krishna's teaching is not for Arjuna alone but for all humanity across all time.

commentary.dadaji: The Lord says 'hanta' — a warm, affectionate 'yes, of course!' — before beginning the great catalogue of vibhutis. There is joy in this response, as if a father is delighted by his child's eagerness to know more about him. And with characteristic divine honesty, He adds: 'but there is no end to My extent — I can only give you the highlights.' This combination of total willingness and infinite transcendence is the mark of the Divine: always available, never exhaustible. The spiritual life with such a God is never boring — always there is more to discover, more to love, more to become.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The exclamation 'hanta' — translated variously as 'good,' 'yes,' 'well then' — is unique in the Gita; it conveys an informal, affectionate delight in the disciple's eagerness. It mirrors the guru-disciple intimacy that is the highest form of spiritual relationship. The Lord's caveat — 'prādhānyataḥ, only the prominent ones' — is important: the entire universe is full of vibhutis without exception, but the mind cannot contemplate infinity directly. The enumeration that follows is a representative selection — an upāya (skillful means) to train the mind in divine vision. Once the mind learns to see God in the prominent, it begins spontaneously to find the Lord in everything.
commentary.yogananda: The Lord's cheerful 'hanta' — his yes to Arjuna's request — is the divine response that every sincere devotee eventually receives: God is infinitely willing to reveal Himself to those who truly seek. The qualification 'only the prominent ones, for there is no end to My extent' is the Lord's gentle reminder that even the most comprehensive teaching is only a beginning. The spiritual path has no ceiling — every realisation opens to a wider realisation, every experience of the Divine deepens to reveal a still more infinite depth. This is not a frustration but the greatest possible good news: there is always more of God to discover.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord's response beginning with 'hanta' represents His genuine willingness to teach — this is the guru-prasāda (grace of the teacher) flowing freely in response to the disciple's earnest inquiry. The phrase 'nāsty anto vistarasya me' — 'there is no end to My extent' — is the most direct statement of the Lord's anantya (infinitude) in the Gita, preparing us for the closing verse of this chapter (42) where He reveals that the entire universe is but an ekāṃśa (single fraction) of Himself. The prominent vibhutis listed in verses 20-41 are thus deliberately exemplary rather than exhaustive — training wheels for the vision that ultimately sees God in all and all in God.

commentary.dadaji: After offering to describe His external manifestations, the Lord first points inward: 'I am the Ātman, dwelling in the heart of all beings.' Before you seek Me in the sun, the mountains, the scriptures — find Me here, in your own heart. This is the most intimate of all vibhutis and the most accessible. The beginning, middle, and end of every being — meaning that before birth, in life, and at death, it is always the same Ātman present, unchanged. This is the deepest security possible: the one who holds you from before birth to beyond death is the very Lord to whom you pray.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This is the summit of the Vibhuti Yoga — the first and highest vibhūti is Brahman as the Ātman, the inner Self of all beings. The Kaṭha Upanishad declares: 'The Self, smaller than the small, greater than the great, is hidden in the heart of this creature' — this is exactly what Krishna affirms. The declaration 'ādiś ca madhyaṃ ca antaḥ' mirrors the Vedantic teaching of Brahman as the material cause — the very substance from which beings arise, in which they subsist, and into which they dissolve. This makes the external vibhutis that follow (vv. 21-41) secondary to this primary declaration: the first and most complete vibhūti is the Ātman itself.
commentary.yogananda: God begins His catalogue of divine manifestations by pointing to His most intimate presence: 'I am the Self in all hearts.' Before the sun, before Meru, before Ganga — here is the greatest vibhūti, the most accessible and most glorious: the Presence that is closer than breathing, nearer than heartbeat. The beginning, middle, and end of all beings in God means that the divine ground underlies every moment of every life — waking, dreaming, sleeping, dying. There is no moment in which you are not already held in the arms of the Infinite. All meditation is simply becoming conscious of what was always already the case.
commentary.goyandka: The opening statement of the vibhūti enumeration — 'aham ātmā... sarvabhūtāśayasthitaḥ' — is at once the most philosophical and the most devotionally rich declaration in this chapter. As Ātman, Krishna is identical with the ultimate reality of all beings — not their body, mind, or personality, but their deepest identity. The Brahma-sūtras begin: 'athāto brahma jijñāsā' — the inquiry into Brahman; here Brahman Himself provides the answer: 'I am that which you are seeking — seek no further than your own heart.' The declaration of being 'beginning, middle, and end' establishes Krishna's causality at every level: upādāna (material), nimitta (efficient), and pariṇāmi (transformative) cause — all three collapsed into the one divine Self.

commentary.dadaji: In this verse, Shri Krishna begins the grand enumeration of His divine glories, inviting us to see the sacred in the everyday cosmos. When you gaze at the Sun each morning and feel its life-giving warmth, know that you are glimpsing Krishna Himself. The Moon that soothes the night sky, the wind that carries life — these are not mere natural phenomena but living expressions of the Divine. Make a practice of pausing before the Sun and the Moon with this remembrance; it will transform mundane moments into acts of worship.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse opens the Vibhuti Yoga with a cosmological vision deeply consonant with the Upanishadic teaching that Brahman alone is all this. The Adityas are the twelve solar aspects governing time and cosmic order; among them Krishna declares Himself to be Vishnu, the all-pervading. The Chandogya Upanishad states 'sarvam khalv idam brahma' — all this is indeed Brahman. Krishna here translates that abstract non-dual truth into a devotional catalogue: wherever there is the pre-eminent in any category, there is the fullest manifestation of the Self.
commentary.yogananda: The Sun is the great cosmic transmitter of divine energy to our solar system; when Krishna says He is the radiant Sun among luminaries, He points to the central dynamo of spiritual light behind all physical illumination. Marichi as the chief Marut represents the pranic life-force moving through creation — the same prana that flows in your breath and animates your meditation. In deep contemplation, the inner Moon-light of the cooling, reflective mind merges with the solar fire of wisdom. These vibhutis are invitations to trace every dazzling phenomenon back to the one luminous Source.
commentary.goyandka: Bhagavan Shri Krishna begins His enumeration of divine manifestations by establishing His identity with the highest representative of each cosmic order. Among the twelve Adityas, Vishnu stands supreme as the pervader of all; among the Maruts, Marichi is the foremost. The Moon governs the mind through its influence on the twenty-seven nakṣatras. The traditional commentators note that Krishna is specifically the most glorious in each class to indicate that wherever excellence appears, it is nothing but His śakti expressing itself.

commentary.dadaji: The Sama Veda is pure music offered to God — Krishna says He is that very music, reminding us that devotional song is one of the closest paths to the Divine. Vasava, the king of gods, embodies divine sovereignty; when you acknowledge divine order in the world, you touch Krishna. Most intimately, He declares Himself to be the mind among the senses and consciousness in all beings. This means the very awareness with which you read these words is Krishna. How wonderful — you need not travel anywhere to find Him.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The identification with cetanā — consciousness — is the most philosophically profound statement in this verse. Advaita Vedanta holds that pure Consciousness (Cit) is the nature of Brahman itself, and here Krishna makes that teaching explicit. The Sama Veda, with its melodic elaborations of the Rig mantras, was considered the most sublime of the four Vedas and is praised in the Chandogya Upanishad as the essence of all scriptures. By identifying Himself with mind and consciousness, Krishna locates the Divine not in distant heavens but in the very instrument of our knowing.
commentary.yogananda: Among all scriptures, the Sama Veda is the Veda of cosmic sound — its chants vibrate at frequencies that open the inner ear to the Aum. Krishna's identification with cetanā, consciousness, is the key to the deepest meditation: when you sit in stillness and become aware of awareness itself, you are touching Krishna directly. The mind, when purified through pranayama and meditation, becomes the divine telescope through which the soul perceives God. Consciousness is not produced by the brain; the brain is a receiving station for the infinite Consciousness which Krishna declares as His own essence.
commentary.goyandka: The Sama Veda holds a special position among the four Vedas because its mantras are sung in specific melodic patterns (sāmans), making it the foundation of the Udgītha worship and the science of nāda. Indra as Vāsava is the chief among the thirty-three categories of devas who govern the cosmic functions. The declaration 'manaś ca asmi indriyāṇām' establishes the mind as the controller of the ten sense organs — it is the doorkeeper of all experience. Cetanā as the life-principle distinguishing the animate from the inanimate is the direct presence of Paramātmā in all beings, as confirmed in the Kaṭha Upanishad's teaching of the jīva residing in the heart.

commentary.dadaji: Shankara — the one who bestows auspiciousness — is Krishna's own vibhuti among the Rudras, showing that the apparent distinction between Shiva and Vishnu dissolves in the light of the Supreme. Agni, the sacred fire, is the purifier among the Vasus; every ritual fire lit in the home is therefore a direct encounter with Krishna. Mount Meru, the immovable golden axis of the cosmos, symbolises the unwavering centre of your own being. In your spiritual practice, aspire to become like Meru — steady and luminous at the centre, no matter what storms revolve around you.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse beautifully dissolves sectarian boundaries by identifying Krishna with Shankara — the supreme Shiva. The Vedantic tradition recognises that Shiva and Vishnu are two names for the one Brahman seen through different upādhis. The eleven Rudras are aspects of the transformative power inherent in Brahman. Agni (Pavaka, the purifier) holds a unique position in Vedic cosmology as the mediator between the human and divine planes — the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa calls fire the mouth of the gods. Mount Meru as the cosmic axis represents the stability of the Absolute that underlies all apparent change.
commentary.yogananda: The sacred fire of Agni is the outer symbol of the inner fire of jñāna that burns away all karmic dross. When Shankara is named as the foremost Rudra, we are reminded that the cosmic destroyer is simultaneously the greatest liberator — all great transformations in the spiritual life require the grace of that purifying Rudra-force. Mount Meru in yogic symbolism corresponds to the sushumna nadi, the golden axial channel in the spine through which the awakened kundalini rises. Meditate on the spine as Meru — the stable, luminous mountain of the Self — and all the scattered energies of the mind will gather into stillness.
commentary.goyandka: The eleven Rudras represent aspects of prāṇa and the transformative cosmic force; among them Shankara stands as the giver of peace and moksha — and the Gita's identification with Krishna affirms the non-difference of Shiva and Vishnu at the Supreme level. Kubera, the lord of yakṣas and wealth, reminds us that even material prosperity is a manifestation of divine grace when approached with proper dharmic attitude. The eight Vasus have Agni as their most manifest representative since fire sustains all Vedic rites. Meru, described in the Purāṇas as the golden cosmic mountain, is the axis around which all the lokas are arranged — a fitting symbol of the Supreme as the stable support of the entire universe.

commentary.dadaji: Krishna tenderly addresses Arjuna as 'Partha' — son of Pritha — reminding him of the bond of love even in the midst of cosmic teaching. Brihaspati, the divine guru, represents the highest wisdom that guides right action; Krishna saying He is that Guru is His way of telling every sincere seeker that the inner teacher they feel guiding them is none other than the Lord. Skanda, ever young and victorious, is the commander of the divine army — symbolising that when you take up the battle against ignorance and ego, Krishna Himself leads your forces. The ocean's vastness and depth hold all waters yet remain untroubled — meditate on this as the nature of your own heart.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Brihaspati — literally 'the Lord of the vast' — embodies the principle of divine wisdom (prajñā) in its role as guide and illuminator. In the hierarchy of knowledge, the preceptor who transmits the liberating wisdom of the Self is the highest among all functionaries; by identifying Himself with Brihaspati, Krishna affirms that the guru-disciple relationship is a sacred channel of the Divine. Skanda was born of Shiva's fiery seed to destroy the demon Taraka — representing the force of discriminative knowledge (viveka) that annihilates ignorance. The ocean's identification here recalls the Upanishadic simile of individual rivers merging into the sea — the ocean is Brahman into which all individual consciousnesses eventually resolve.
commentary.yogananda: Brihaspati, the guru of the gods, channels divine wisdom from the cosmic Source into the angelic intelligences — he represents the inner teacher whose guidance reaches the sincere devotee through intuition and inner prompting. Skanda, also called Karttikeya, is worshipped as the deity of the sixth chakra (ajna) in certain tantric systems — the commander of the spiritual armies that wage the inner war against vasanas and samskaras. The ocean as God's vibhuti speaks to the infinite receptivity of samadhi consciousness — the ocean receives all rivers without discrimination and without being diminished. In deep meditation, the small self dissolves like a river entering the vast ocean of divine Being.
commentary.goyandka: Among all royal priests, Bṛhaspati holds the supreme position as the guru of the thirty-three devas, the wielder of Brahmanaspati mantra-power that upholds the cosmic dharmic order. His identification with Krishna underscores that the supreme priestly office is itself a divine vibhuti, reminding householders to honour their family guru as a direct form of God. Skanda, born to lead the celestial forces against adharmic powers, represents the victory of righteousness (dharma-vijaya); commanders who fight for just causes embody this vibhuti. The sāgara among all sarasas is foremost because it is the source and final resting place of all waters — the father of all rivers in the Purāṇic tradition.

commentary.dadaji: Of all the practices a devotee can take up, Krishna singles out japa — the repetition of God's name — as the highest sacrifice. This is remarkable encouragement for each of us: you need no ritual paraphernalia, no priest, no auspicious timing. Anywhere, at any time, the quiet turning of the divine name in your heart is a direct offering to Krishna. The single syllable Om contains the entire teaching of the Upanishads in one breath. And the Himalayas, the abode of sages and silence, remind us that our own stillness is the most sacred place we can inhabit.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The ekam akṣaram — the single imperishable syllable Om — is the most concentrated symbol of Brahman in the entire Vedic tradition. The Mandukya Upanishad devotes itself entirely to the analysis of this one syllable, declaring 'Aum iti etat sarvam' — all this is Om. Japa as the supreme yajña is significant because in a yajña something is surrendered into fire; in japa, the separate ego is incrementally surrendered into the fire of the divine Name — making it the most interior and therefore most spiritually potent of all sacrifices. Bhrigu, the cosmic lawgiver and tester of the Trimurti, represents the highest sattvik wisdom among the progenitor sages.
commentary.yogananda: Om is the Word of God — what Saint John calls 'the Word that was in the beginning' and what the Vedas call the primordial nāda from which the entire universe was projected. When Krishna says He is that single syllable, He is revealing that the cosmic creative vibration and He are identical. Japa is the most scientific of spiritual practices: the rhythmic repetition of a divine name or mantra synchronises the nervous system with higher vibratory planes, gradually dissolving the mental turbulence that obscures the soul's perception of God. The Himalayas are the eternal abode of tapas — that majestic stillness which all meditators aspire to internalise.
commentary.goyandka: Sage Bhṛgu is foremost among the seven great cosmic sages (saptarṣis) because of his unrivalled tapas and his role in creating the Bhrigu Smriti, a foundational dharmaśāstra text. The primacy of Om (praṇava) among all speech-forms has been established in the Taittirīya Upanishad: 'Aum iti Brahma, Aum itīdaṃ sarvam' — Om is Brahman, Om is all this. The superiority of japayajña over all external yajñas is confirmed by the Manusmriti, which declares japa the greatest tapas. The Himalayas, called Himavān in the Purāṇas, are the father-in-law of Shiva and the abode of countless siddhas and ṛṣis — their immovability across cosmic cycles makes them the supreme representative of the sthāvara category.

commentary.dadaji: The Ashvattha tree is revered in every Indian village — people circumambulate it, pour water at its roots, and tie sacred threads to its branches. Krishna says He dwells there. So the grandmother who waters the pipal in the morning courtyard is worshipping Krishna without even knowing it — such is the grace of this vision. Narada, the eternal bhakta who wanders the cosmos singing 'Narayana Narayana,' is the greatest of divine sages precisely because his whole existence is unbroken devotion. Let Narada's example inspire you: make every breath a quiet chant, every step a pilgrimage.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Ashvattha tree holds a singular place in Vedic and Gita symbolism — in Chapter 15, Krishna describes the eternal Ashvattha of samsara with roots above and branches below. Here in Chapter 10, the Ashvattha as the greatest tree suggests that even the symbol of the phenomenal world, when understood rightly, points back to Brahman. Narada as the foremost devarṣi embodies the principle that the highest wisdom is not dry knowledge but wisdom soaked in love — bhakti-jñāna integrated. Kapila's Sankhya philosophy is recognised as the most systematic analytical account of the cosmos in the Indian tradition, making him the foremost among the Siddhas who have achieved both philosophical clarity and yogic mastery.
commentary.yogananda: The sacred fig or Bodhi tree — Ashvattha — is the tree under which the Buddha attained enlightenment, and it represents in yogic symbolism the inverted tree of life with roots in the Infinite. Narada, the divine troubadour, carries the vibrations of divine love across all the planes of existence — he represents the current of bhakti that flows upward from the heart chakra to unite with cosmic Consciousness. Kapila, the founder of Sankhya, achieved liberation through pure discriminative wisdom (viveka), mapping the twenty-five tattvas of existence — his Siddhahood is the proof that rigorous intellectual inquiry, when taken to its ultimate conclusion, dissolves into the same samadhi that devotion achieves by another path.
commentary.goyandka: The Ashvattha (Pipal) is described in the Atharva Veda as the dwelling-place of Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva simultaneously — no other tree receives this triple honour, making it the most sacred of all trees. Devarṣi Nārada is distinguished from brahmarṣis and rājarṣis by virtue of his constant access to all three worlds and his role as the foremost disseminator of hari-kathā; his Nārada Bhakti Sūtras remain the definitive text on the science of devotion. Chitraratha, king of the Gandharvas, presides over the celestial art of music — all true beauty in art is a partial expression of divine glory. Kapila Muni, son of Kardama and Devahuti, is considered an avatāra of Vishnu in the Bhāgavata Purāṇa — his Sankhya revelation is thus not merely a philosophical system but a direct divine disclosure.

commentary.dadaji: Both Ucchaihshravas and Airavata arose from the Samudra Manthan — the churning of the cosmic ocean — which is one of the most beloved stories of the Puranas. They are born of divine grace, unblemished and radiant. Krishna says 'know Me as these.' Among humans, He is the king — the one whose dharmic rule upholds the welfare of all. Pray that your leaders be touched by this divine vibhuti and rule with wisdom and compassion. And remember that the highest king is the one who has first conquered the inner kingdom of the senses.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The repeated use of 'viddhi' — 'know' — is instructive: Krishna is asking Arjuna to shift his mode of knowing, from ordinary empirical perception to a vision that recognises the Divine Presence sustaining all excellence. Ucchaihshravas and Airavata, born of amrita during the cosmic churning, represent manifestations that arise directly from the ocean of Brahman. The king as the supreme among humans carries a teaching about social dharma: a just king (rājadharmī) is a vibhuti — he embodies divine order on earth. The Arthashastra and Manusmriti both describe kingship as a sacred responsibility, a form of worship.
commentary.yogananda: Ucchaihshravas, the celestial white horse, symbolises the perfectly controlled life-force — the prana that has been elevated (uccais, meaning 'high') through spiritual practice and now serves as a swift vehicle for the soul's ascent. Airavata, the four-tusked white elephant, represents the fourfold mind (manas, buddhi, chitta, ahamkara) in its purified, powerful state — massive in capacity, yet perfectly obedient to divine direction. The king among humans is the one who has conquered the kingdom of the inner senses first — real sovereignty is self-mastery. Outer kingship is a vibhuti only when it flows from inner sovereignty.
commentary.goyandka: The Samudra Manthan episode, described in the Viṣṇu Purāṇa and Bhāgavata Purāṇa, produced fourteen ratnas (divine treasures) including Ucchaihshravas and Airāvata — both belonging to Indra. Ucchaihshravas is described as seven-headed, pure white, and capable of crossing all three worlds — its amṛtodbhava origin makes it wholly untouched by the tamasic qualities of ordinary samsara. Among humans, the dharmic king (dharmarāja) is the supreme vibhuti because his role in protecting the social order allows thousands of souls to progress on their spiritual journey — making righteous rule a form of collective service to God.
